meaning: To initiate conversation in a social setting and reduce tension.
example_1: He told a joke to break the ice at the beginning of the meeting.
example_2: A fun activity helped the students break the ice on the first day of class.
quiz_options: To begin a conversation and ease tension
To go outside in cold weather

meaning: To rain very heavily.
example_1: We had to cancel the picnic because it was raining cats and dogs.
example_2: It’s raining cats and dogs — don’t forget your umbrella!
quiz_options: To walk pets in the rain
To have a storm with animals

meaning: To look extremely angry or upset.
example_1: When she saw the broken vase, she had a face like thunder.
example_2: He walked into the room with a face like thunder after hearing the bad news.

meaning: A lot of fuss about something unimportant.
example_1: Their argument was just a storm in a teacup — nothing serious.
example_2: The media turned a minor issue into a storm in a teacup.
quiz_options: A small issue blown out of proportion

meaning: To pursue unrealistic or impossible goals.
example_1: He’s always chasing rainbows instead of focusing on real opportunities.
example_2: Trying to become famous overnight is just chasing rainbows.

meaning: Extremely fast or quick.
example_1: Her reaction to the question was lightning-fast.
example_2: The new processor makes the computer lightning-fast.

idiom: have one's head in the clouds
meaning: To be out of touch with reality or lost in daydreams.
example_1: She always has her head in the clouds during meetings.
example_2: Stop daydreaming — you’ve got your head in the clouds again!

meaning: To be overwhelmed with too much work or tasks.
example_1: I’m snowed under with deadlines this week.
example_2: She was snowed under and couldn’t attend the meeting.

meaning: To feel slightly ill or unwell.
example_1: I’m feeling under the weather today, so I’ll stay home.
example_2: She looked under the weather and left early.
quiz_options: To be outside in bad weather

meaning: To be left in a vulnerable or uncertain situation without support.
example_1: He was left to twist in the wind after the team abandoned him.
example_2: Without clear instructions, the interns twisted in the wind.
quiz_options: To be left uncertain and exposed

meaning: To be suspected of wrongdoing or dishonesty.
example_1: He left the company under a cloud after the audit.
example_2: She’s under a cloud because of the missing funds.
quiz_options: To be outside in bad weather

meaning: To feel perfectly fine or healthy.
example_1: After a good night’s sleep, I felt as right as rain.
example_2: She was ill yesterday, but today she’s as right as rain.

meaning: To save something, usually money, for future difficulties.
example_1: I keep some savings for a rainy day.
example_2: She put aside a little money for a rainy day.
quiz_options: To go shopping in the rain

meaning: A sudden and unexpected event or piece of news.
example_1: His resignation was a bolt from the blue.
example_2: The news of the merger came like a bolt from the blue.

meaning: To act recklessly or take a risk without worrying about the consequences.
example_1: He threw caution to the winds and invested all his savings.
example_2: She threw caution to the winds and quit her job to travel.

meaning: To survive a difficult situation or period.
example_1: The company managed to weather the storm during the crisis.
example_2: They weathered the storm and came out stronger.

meaning: To take risks or behave in a way that is almost improper or illegal.
example_1: He’s always sailing close to the wind with his tax returns.
example_2: That comment sailed close to the wind — be careful.
quiz_options: To take risks or act improperly

meaning: To be extremely happy or joyful.
example_1: She was on cloud nine after getting the job offer.
example_2: He’s been on cloud nine since his wedding day.

meaning: To chat casually about unimportant things.
example_1: We sat on the porch and shot the breeze for hours.
example_2: They love shooting the breeze over coffee every morning.

meaning: To be confused or unable to think clearly.
example_1: After the long flight, I was completely in a fog.
example_2: She’s been in a fog since hearing the bad news.

meaning: To be very successful or well received.
example_1: Her presentation went down a storm with the audience.
example_2: The new product went down a storm at the launch event.

meaning: A share of something valuable, especially money or benefits.
example_1: Everyone wants a piece of the pie when the profits are high.
example_2: He demanded a piece of the pie after helping with the project.

meaning: A situation where someone makes money with little effort.
example_1: He’s riding the gravy train with that cushy government job.
example_2: They got off the gravy train when the funding stopped.
quiz_options: A profitable situation with little effort

meaning: To earn money to support a household.
example_1: She works hard to bring home the bacon for her family.
example_2: He finally brought home the bacon with his new business.
quiz_options: To earn money for the family

meaning: To manage financially, especially with difficulty.
example_1: They struggle to make ends meet on a single income.
example_2: After losing his job, he could barely make ends meet.

meaning: To have great success or win a large amount of money.
example_1: She hit the jackpot with her new startup.
example_2: He hit the jackpot at the casino last night.
quiz_options: To win big or succeed greatly

meaning: To owe money or be in financial trouble.
example_1: The company has been in the red for three quarters.
example_2: After the holiday spending, I’m in the red again.

meaning: To earn a large amount of money.
example_1: He made a bundle selling vintage vinyl records.
example_2: They made a bundle after launching their app.
quiz_options: To earn a lot of money

meaning: To be absolutely sure about something.
example_1: You can bet your bottom dollar he’ll be late again.
example_2: I bet my bottom dollar that she’ll win the competition.

meaning: To look extremely attractive or well-dressed.
example_1: She looked like a million dollars in that dress.
example_2: After the makeover, he looked like a million dollars.

meaning: To be very expensive.
example_1: That designer bag cost a pretty penny.
example_2: Fixing the car is going to cost a pretty penny.

meaning: To split the cost of something, especially a meal.
example_1: Let’s go Dutch on dinner tonight.
example_2: They always go Dutch when they eat out.

meaning: A sum of money saved for the future, especially for retirement.
example_1: They’ve built a nice nest egg for their retirement.
example_2: She keeps a small nest egg in case of emergencies.

meaning: A large sum of money given to someone when they leave a job.
example_1: He received a golden handshake when he retired from the company.
example_2: The CEO left with a golden handshake worth millions.

meaning: A person who is unwilling to spend money.
example_1: Don’t be such a cheapskate — it’s just a coffee.
example_2: He’s known as a cheapskate who never tips.

meaning: To have a lot of money available.
example_1: After the deal, they were flush with money.
example_2: She’s flush with money after her promotion.

meaning: No matter what the effort or expense, something must be done.
example_1: We must protect the data at all costs.
example_2: She wanted to win the competition at all costs.

meaning: To spend more money than one can afford.
example_1: He’s living beyond his means with that luxury car.
example_2: Many people live beyond their means and fall into debt.

meaning: To cost too much or use up all of one’s money.
example_1: Buying that car won’t break the bank.
example_2: The vacation broke the bank, but it was worth it.

meaning: To be extremely expensive.
example_1: That designer dress cost a fortune.
example_2: Renovating the house will cost a fortune.

meaning: To be extremely poor or living at a minimum level.
example_1: After losing his job, he was on the breadline.
example_2: Many families are living on the breadline due to inflation.

meaning: Something that happens very infrequently.
example_1: We go out to dinner once in a blue moon.
example_2: He visits his hometown once in a blue moon.

meaning: Not keeping up with current trends or technology.
example_1: His fashion sense is really behind the times.
example_2: That company is behind the times with its outdated software.

meaning: Time passes very quickly.
example_1: Time flies when you're having fun.
example_2: It’s already September — time really flies!

meaning: A state of great success or fame.
example_1: She finally made it to the big time with her new album.
example_2: He’s playing in the big time now — national league!

meaning: Continuously, all day and night.
example_1: The store is open around the clock.
example_2: They worked around the clock to finish the project.

meaning: To think too much about past events, especially negative ones.
example_1: You shouldn’t dwell on the past — focus on the future.
example_2: He keeps dwelling on the past and can’t move forward.
quiz_options: To think too much about the past

idiom: have the time of one's life
meaning: To enjoy oneself greatly.
example_1: We had the time of our lives on vacation.
example_2: She had the time of her life at the concert.

meaning: Very early in the morning.
example_1: We left at the crack of dawn to catch the train.
example_2: She wakes up at the crack of dawn every day.

meaning: To have no time left to complete something.
example_1: We ran out of time before finishing the exam.
example_2: She ran out of time and couldn’t submit the report.

idiom: in the blink of an eye
meaning: Very quickly; almost instantly.
example_1: The car disappeared in the blink of an eye.
example_2: It was over in the blink of an eye — so fast!

meaning: To happen regularly or predictably, without problems.
example_1: The trains run like clockwork in Japan.
example_2: Her morning routine goes like clockwork.

meaning: For a very long time.
example_1: They’ve lived in that house for donkey’s years.
example_2: I haven’t seen him for donkey’s years — maybe since school.

meaning: To have very little time available.
example_1: I’m really pressed for time — can we talk later?
example_2: She was pressed for time and skipped lunch.

meaning: To criticize or treat someone harshly.
example_1: The teacher gave me a hard time for being late.
example_2: Don’t give him a hard time — he’s doing his best.

meaning: To be early or more advanced than expected.
example_1: We finished the project ahead of time.
example_2: Her ideas were ahead of time and not understood back then.

idiom: have a whale of a time
meaning: To enjoy oneself greatly.
example_1: We had a whale of a time at the beach.
example_2: She had a whale of a time dancing at the party.

meaning: To adapt to modern ideas or changes.
example_1: You need to go with the times and learn new tech.
example_2: The company went with the times and updated its branding.

idiom: on the spur of the moment
meaning: Suddenly and without planning.
example_1: We decided to go to the beach on the spur of the moment.
example_2: He bought the car on the spur of the moment.

meaning: In plain view during the daytime.
example_1: The robbery happened in broad daylight.
example_2: She was attacked in broad daylight near the station.

meaning: To surprise someone unexpectedly.
example_1: The storm caught us unawares while hiking.
example_2: She was caught unawares by the sudden question.

meaning: Silly or dishonest behavior; unproductive activity.
example_1: Stop the monkey business and get back to work.
example_2: There’s been some monkey business with the budget figures.

meaning: To suspect that something is wrong or dishonest.
example_1: I smelled a rat when he avoided the question.
example_2: She smells a rat in the sudden change of plans.

meaning: The most important or successful person in a group.
example_1: He became the top dog in the company after the merger.
example_2: Everyone wants to be the top dog in politics.

meaning: A product or business that generates a steady income.
example_1: That app is their cash cow — it brings in millions.
example_2: The subscription model became a cash cow for the company.

meaning: A person who works very hard and enthusiastically.
example_1: She’s an eager beaver — always first to arrive.
example_2: The eager beaver finished the project ahead of schedule.

meaning: A person who is different from others in a group and often disapproved of.
example_1: He’s the black sheep of the family — always in trouble.
example_2: She felt like the black sheep at the office party.
quiz_options: A person who stands out negatively

meaning: An obvious issue that people avoid discussing.
example_1: Nobody mentioned the budget cuts — the elephant in the room.
example_2: The divorce was the elephant in the room during dinner.

meaning: Something that will never happen.
example_1: He’ll clean his room when pigs fly.
example_2: She’ll apologize? When pigs fly!

idiom: like a cat on a hot tin roof
meaning: To be extremely nervous or restless.
example_1: He was like a cat on a hot tin roof before the interview.
example_2: She paced the room like a cat on a hot tin roof.

meaning: To be in trouble or disfavor with someone.
example_1: He forgot her birthday and is now in the doghouse.
example_2: She’s in the doghouse with her boss for missing the deadline.

idiom: be as busy as a bee
meaning: To be very busy and active.
example_1: She’s as busy as a bee preparing for the event.
example_2: He’s been as busy as a bee since morning.

idiom: let the cat out of the bag
meaning: To reveal a secret unintentionally.
example_1: He let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.
example_2: She accidentally let the cat out of the bag during lunch.

meaning: To behave in a silly or careless way, often causing disruption.
example_1: The kids were horsing around in the classroom.
example_2: Stop horsing around and help me clean up!

idiom: as poor as a church mouse
meaning: Extremely poor; having very little money.
example_1: After losing his job, he was as poor as a church mouse.
example_2: She grew up as poor as a church mouse in a small village.

meaning: The largest portion of something.
example_1: He took the lion’s share of the credit for the project.
example_2: The marketing team received the lion’s share of the budget.

meaning: To eat a lot; to have a big appetite.
example_1: He eats like a horse after training.
example_2: Teenagers often eat like horses during growth spurts.

idiom: have a tiger by the tail
meaning: To be involved in something difficult or dangerous that is hard to control.
example_1: Managing that project is like having a tiger by the tail.
example_2: He realized he had a tiger by the tail when the media got involved.

idiom: hear it straight from the horse's mouth
meaning: To get information directly from the person involved.
example_1: I heard it straight from the horse’s mouth — she’s quitting.
example_2: If you want the truth, ask him directly and hear it from the horse’s mouth.
quiz_options: To hear directly from the source

meaning: To feel nervous or anxious, especially before an important event.
example_1: I always get butterflies in my stomach before speaking in public.
example_2: She had butterflies in her stomach before the big exam.

idiom: like water off a duck's back
meaning: To have no effect on someone; to be easily ignored.
example_1: Criticism rolls off him like water off a duck’s back.
example_2: Her calm attitude made the insults like water off a duck’s back.

meaning: A very studious or intellectual person.
example_1: He’s a real egghead — always buried in books.
example_2: The team hired an egghead to optimize the algorithm.
quiz_options: A very smart or academic person

meaning: An important or influential person.
example_1: He’s the big cheese in the marketing department.
example_2: Everyone listened when the big cheese entered the room.

meaning: A person who spends a lot of time sitting and watching TV.
example_1: He turned into a couch potato during the holidays.
example_2: Don’t be a couch potato — go for a walk!
quiz_options: A lazy person who watches TV

meaning: A strong, determined, or resilient person.
example_1: She’s a tough cookie — nothing gets her down.
example_2: Don’t mess with him, he’s a tough cookie.

meaning: The most important person in a group or organization.
example_1: He’s the top banana in the company now.
example_2: She became the top banana after the promotion.

meaning: A person who negatively influences others in a group.
example_1: One bad apple can spoil the whole team.
example_2: He was fired for being a bad apple in the department.

meaning: To admit that what one said was wrong.
example_1: He had to eat his words after the prediction failed.
example_2: She ate her words when the project succeeded.

meaning: Someone who is cherished and loved deeply.
example_1: His daughter is the apple of his eye.
example_2: She treats her dog like the apple of her eye.

meaning: A difficult problem or person to deal with.
example_1: This puzzle is a hard nut to crack.
example_2: He’s a hard nut to crack — very private and quiet.

meaning: In a very brief and clear way.
example_1: In a nutshell, we need more funding.
example_2: She explained the plan in a nutshell.

meaning: To be embarrassed after doing something wrong or foolish.
example_1: He had egg on his face after the failed presentation.
example_2: She had egg on her face when her prediction was wrong.

meaning: Very calm and composed, especially under pressure.
example_1: She stayed as cool as a cucumber during the interview.
example_2: Even in crisis, he’s as cool as a cucumber.

meaning: To be very energetic, lively, or enthusiastic.
example_1: The kids were full of beans after the birthday party.
example_2: She’s always full of beans in the morning.

meaning: Extremely slow.
example_1: The traffic was as slow as molasses this morning.
example_2: He moves as slow as molasses when getting ready.

meaning: To chat casually, especially about unimportant things.
example_1: We sat around chewing the fat all evening.
example_2: They love to chew the fat over coffee every morning.

meaning: To sell very quickly and in large quantities.
example_1: The new phones are selling like hot cakes.
example_2: Her handmade jewelry sells like hot cakes at the market.

idiom: take something with a pinch of salt
meaning: To not completely believe something; to be skeptical.
example_1: Take his story with a pinch of salt — he tends to exaggerate.
example_2: I take online reviews with a pinch of salt.

idiom: bite off more than one can chew
meaning: To take on a task that is too difficult or too much to handle.
example_1: He bit off more than he could chew by accepting two jobs.
example_2: She realized she’d bitten off more than she could chew with the renovation.
quiz_options: To take on too much responsibility

meaning: To be upset about something that cannot be changed.
example_1: It’s no use crying over spilt milk — just move on.
example_2: She cried over spilt milk after losing the file.
quiz_options: To be upset about something irreversible

meaning: A controversial or difficult issue that people avoid dealing with.
example_1: The tax reform is a political hot potato.
example_2: The topic of layoffs became a hot potato in the meeting.

meaning: To work or study late into the night.
example_1: She burned the midnight oil to finish her thesis.
example_2: He’s been burning the midnight oil preparing for exams.
quiz_options: To work late into the night

meaning: To go to bed or go to sleep.
example_1: I’m exhausted — time to hit the hay.
example_2: He hit the hay right after dinner.

translation: предложить сказать, о чём думает человек
meaning: A way to ask someone what they are thinking.
example_1: You’ve been quiet — a penny for your thoughts?
example_2: She looked puzzled, so I said, 'A penny for your thoughts.'
quiz_options: To ask what someone is thinking

meaning: To endure something unpleasant or difficult with courage.
example_1: She bit the bullet and went to the dentist.
example_2: He had to bite the bullet and accept the criticism.

idiom: the ball is in your court
meaning: It’s your responsibility to take action or make a decision.
example_1: I’ve done my part — now the ball is in your court.
example_2: She gave him the offer, and now the ball is in his court.

meaning: To tease or joke with someone in a playful way.
example_1: Relax, I’m just pulling your leg!
example_2: He pulled my leg about winning the lottery.

idiom: hit the nail on the head
meaning: To describe a situation or problem exactly and accurately.
example_1: You hit the nail on the head with that analysis.
example_2: Her comment really hit the nail on the head.

meaning: To do more than what is expected or required.
example_1: She always goes the extra mile to help her clients.
example_2: He went the extra mile and stayed late to finish the project.

meaning: Suddenly and unexpectedly.
example_1: He called me out of the blue after years of silence.
example_2: The offer came out of the blue — I wasn’t even looking for a job.

meaning: To watch or monitor something or someone carefully.
example_1: Can you keep an eye on my bag while I’m gone?
example_2: She kept an eye on the kids at the playground.

meaning: To be in the same situation as someone else, especially a difficult one.
example_1: We’re all in the same boat — struggling with deadlines.
example_2: She felt better knowing others were in the same boat.
quiz_options: To be in the same situation

meaning: To stop working for the day or to end an activity.
example_1: Let’s call it a day and continue tomorrow.
example_2: After five hours of coding, I called it a day.
quiz_options: To end work for the day

meaning: To destroy relationships or opportunities permanently.
example_1: He burned bridges with his former employer.
example_2: Don’t burn bridges — you might need their help later.

meaning: To give up or stop trying.
example_1: After several failed attempts, he threw in the towel.
example_2: She refused to throw in the towel despite the challenges.

meaning: To pursue a mistaken or misguided course of action.
example_1: If you think I’m responsible, you’re barking up the wrong tree.
example_2: They were barking up the wrong tree by blaming the intern.
quiz_options: To make a mistake in judgment

meaning: To leave or begin a journey.
example_1: Let’s hit the road before traffic gets bad.
example_2: They hit the road early to catch the sunrise.

meaning: To argue against a position for the sake of debate or testing ideas.
example_1: Let me play devil’s advocate and challenge that assumption.
example_2: She played devil’s advocate to help refine the proposal.
quiz_options: To argue for the sake of debate

meaning: To advance in one's career, especially within a company.
example_1: He’s been climbing the corporate ladder for years.
example_2: She hopes to climb the corporate ladder and become a manager.

translation: сразу взяться за дело с энтузиазмом
meaning: To start something quickly and effectively.
example_1: She hit the ground running on her first day at work.
example_2: The team hit the ground running after the strategy meeting.

meaning: To think creatively and differently from the usual approach.
example_1: We need to think outside the box to solve this problem.
example_2: Her idea was brilliant — she really thought outside the box.

meaning: To set a higher standard or level of expectation.
example_1: Her performance raised the bar for the whole team.
example_2: They raised the bar with their new product launch.

meaning: To learn how to do a job or activity properly.
example_1: It took me a few weeks to learn the ropes at my new job.
example_2: She’s still learning the ropes but improving fast.
quiz_options: To learn the basics of a job

meaning: To do something in the easiest or cheapest way, often sacrificing quality.
example_1: They cut corners on safety to save money.
example_2: Don’t cut corners — do it properly.
quiz_options: To take shortcuts and reduce quality

idiom: burn the candle at both ends
meaning: To work too hard or stay up late, exhausting oneself.
example_1: She’s burning the candle at both ends with work and study.
example_2: He burned the candle at both ends and got sick.
quiz_options: To work excessively and exhaust oneself

meaning: To do your fair share of work or responsibility.
example_1: Everyone needs to pull their weight on this team.
example_2: He wasn’t pulling his weight, so they let him go.

meaning: To join others in doing something that is currently popular.
example_1: Many companies jumped on the bandwagon of AI tools.
example_2: He jumped on the bandwagon and started a podcast.

meaning: To get an initial opportunity that could lead to something bigger.
example_1: This internship is my foot in the door to the industry.
example_2: He got a foot in the door through a friend’s recommendation.

meaning: To follow rules or procedures exactly and strictly.
example_1: She always does everything by the book.
example_2: The audit was conducted by the book — no shortcuts.

meaning: To agree or understand something in the same way.
example_1: Let’s make sure we’re on the same page before we start.
example_2: The team wasn’t on the same page, so the project failed.
quiz_options: To understand something the same way

idiom: put your nose to the grindstone
meaning: To work very hard and diligently.
example_1: He put his nose to the grindstone and finished the report.
example_2: She’s had her nose to the grindstone all week.

meaning: To make contact or briefly communicate.
example_1: Let’s touch base next week about the proposal.
example_2: She touched base with her manager before leaving.

meaning: To be in control or make the decisions.
example_1: She’s the one calling the shots in the team.
example_2: The manager called the shots during the meeting.

meaning: Happening secretly or out of public view.
example_1: A lot of work happens behind the scenes before a launch.
example_2: She’s managing everything behind the scenes.

idiom: at the top of your game
meaning: To be performing at your best level.
example_1: She’s at the top of her game in marketing.
example_2: He was at the top of his game during the tournament.

meaning: To succeed or fail without help.
example_1: New hires are expected to sink or swim.
example_2: He was thrown into the role and had to sink or swim.
quiz_options: To succeed or fail on your own

meaning: An approximate number or estimate.
example_1: Can you give me a ballpark figure for the cost?
example_2: The ballpark figure was around $10,000.

meaning: A critical period when pressure is high and results are needed.
example_1: It’s crunch time — the deadline is tomorrow.
example_2: During crunch time, the team worked overtime.

meaning: A situation where all parties benefit.
example_1: This deal is a win-win situation for both sides.
example_2: They found a win-win solution to the conflict.

meaning: To quickly form a good relationship or connection with someone.
example_1: They hit it off the moment they met.
example_2: I didn’t expect to hit it off with my new colleague so fast.

meaning: To agree or have the same opinion.
example_1: We rarely see eye to eye on politics.
example_2: They see eye to eye on how to raise their children.

meaning: To support someone in good times and bad.
example_1: She stayed with him through thick and thin.
example_2: True friends are there through thick and thin.

meaning: Someone who listens and offers comfort during difficult times.
example_1: After the breakup, she needed a shoulder to cry on.
example_2: He’s always been my shoulder to cry on.

meaning: To understand each other easily, often due to shared values or thinking.
example_1: We speak the same language when it comes to design.
example_2: They speak the same language — no need for long explanations.

idiom: birds of a feather flock together
translation: люди с общими интересами тянутся друг к другу
meaning: People with similar interests or personalities tend to associate with each other.
example_1: All the artists sat together — birds of a feather flock together.
example_2: Gamers often find each other online — birds of a feather.

meaning: To make peace and end a conflict.
example_1: They finally buried the hatchet after years of rivalry.
example_2: Let’s bury the hatchet and move on.

translation: друг, который рядом только в хорошие времена
meaning: Someone who is only supportive when things are going well.
example_1: He turned out to be a fair-weather friend when I lost my job.
example_2: She’s a fair-weather friend — never around during hard times.
quiz_options: A friend only in good times

idiom: like two peas in a pod
meaning: To be very similar or close in appearance or behavior.
example_1: They’re like two peas in a pod — always together.
example_2: The twins are like two peas in a pod.

meaning: To be inseparable or always together.
example_1: Those two are joined at the hip — you never see one without the other.
example_2: They’ve been joined at the hip since childhood.

meaning: An immediate and strong romantic attraction to someone upon first meeting.
example_1: It was love at first sight when they met at the airport.
example_2: He believes in love at first sight — just like in the movies.

meaning: To be completely and deeply in love.
example_1: She’s head over heels in love with her fiancé.
example_2: He fell head over heels in love after their first date.

meaning: To get married.
example_1: They tied the knot in a small ceremony last summer.
example_2: After ten years together, they finally tied the knot.

meaning: To ask someone to marry you.
example_1: He popped the question during their trip to Paris.
example_2: She was shocked when he popped the question at dinner.

idiom: wear your heart on your sleeve
meaning: To openly show your emotions and feelings.
example_1: He wears his heart on his sleeve and never hides his feelings.
example_2: She’s not afraid to wear her heart on her sleeve.

meaning: To impress someone greatly and make them fall in love quickly.
example_1: He swept her off her feet with his charm and kindness.
example_2: She was swept off her feet by the romantic surprise.
quiz_options: To impress and make someone fall in love

meaning: A perfect romantic or working partnership.
example_1: They’re a match made in heaven — so compatible.
example_2: The collaboration was a match made in heaven.

meaning: To cause someone emotional pain, especially in love.
example_1: She broke his heart when she left him.
example_2: It broke my heart to see him cry.

meaning: To reconcile after an argument or disagreement.
example_1: They had a fight but kissed and made up the next day.
example_2: Let’s kiss and make up — this argument isn’t worth it.

meaning: When someone is in love, they may overlook faults or flaws in the other person.
example_1: She forgave him again — love is blind.
example_2: He didn’t notice her selfishness — love is blind, they say.

meaning: In serious trouble or close to failing, especially in relationships.
example_1: Their marriage is on the rocks after months of fighting.
example_2: The partnership is on the rocks due to financial issues.

meaning: To deliberately ignore someone or treat them in an unfriendly way.
example_1: He gave me the cold shoulder after the argument.
example_2: She gave him the cold shoulder at the party.
quiz_options: To ignore or treat someone coldly

idiom: have a soft spot for someone
meaning: To feel affection or fondness for someone, often despite their flaws.
example_1: She has a soft spot for stray animals.
example_2: He has a soft spot for his younger brother.

meaning: To act uninterested or distant to increase someone’s desire or attention.
example_1: She’s playing hard to get to keep him interested.
example_2: He played hard to get, and it worked.
quiz_options: To act uninterested to attract someone

meaning: Something that seems bad at first but results in something good.
example_1: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise — it led to a better opportunity.
example_2: Her injury turned out to be a blessing in disguise, giving her time to write.

meaning: A situation where one can enjoy the benefits of two different things.
example_1: Working remotely gives me the best of both worlds — flexibility and income.
example_2: Living in the suburbs offers the best of both worlds: peace and proximity to the city.

meaning: Very common and not particularly valuable.
example_1: Cheap souvenirs are a dime a dozen in tourist areas.
example_2: Online influencers are a dime a dozen these days.

idiom: get a taste of your own medicine
meaning: To experience the same negative treatment one has given to others.
example_1: He got a taste of his own medicine when his prank backfired.
example_2: She was rude and finally got a taste of her own medicine.
quiz_options: To experience what you’ve done to others

meaning: To accept things as they happen and not resist change.
example_1: I used to plan everything, but now I just go with the flow.
example_2: She went with the flow and ended up enjoying the spontaneous trip.

meaning: To fail, be defeated, or die (figuratively or literally).
example_1: Another startup bit the dust after just six months.
example_2: His old car finally bit the dust last week.

meaning: To skip unnecessary details and get to the main point.
example_1: Let’s cut to the chase — what’s the final decision?
example_2: He cut to the chase and asked for a raise.
quiz_options: To get to the point quickly

meaning: A large sum of money given to someone when they leave a job.
example_1: The CEO received a golden handshake upon retirement.
example_2: He left the company with a golden handshake worth millions.

meaning: To cause trouble or disrupt a stable situation.
example_1: Don’t rock the boat — we’ve just reached an agreement.
example_2: She rocked the boat by questioning the manager’s decision.

meaning: To start an activity or process, especially one that leads to something bigger.
example_1: Let’s get the ball rolling on the new campaign.
example_2: She got the ball rolling by sending the first draft.

idiom: work your fingers to the bone
meaning: To work extremely hard, often to the point of exhaustion.
example_1: She worked her fingers to the bone to support her family.
example_2: He’s been working his fingers to the bone on this report.

meaning: Something that one does not particularly like or enjoy.
example_1: Horror movies are not my cup of tea.
example_2: Camping is fun for some, but it’s not my cup of tea.

meaning: To learn something through difficult or painful experience.
example_1: He learned the hard way not to ignore deadlines.
example_2: She learned the hard way that trust must be earned.

meaning: To attract the most attention or praise, often unexpectedly.
example_1: Her performance stole the show at the event.
example_2: The youngest speaker stole the show with his speech.

meaning: To commit fully and take bold action, or not bother at all.
example_1: He invested everything — go big or go home.
example_2: She went big or went home with her business pitch.
quiz_options: To take bold action or quit

meaning: To be exactly right or accurate.
example_1: Her analysis hit the bull’s eye.
example_2: He hit the bull’s eye with his prediction.

meaning: To become well-known or respected in a particular field.
example_1: She made a name for herself in tech.
example_2: He made a name for himself as a designer.

meaning: To finalize or secure an agreement.
example_1: He clinched the deal after a long negotiation.
example_2: Her presentation clinched the deal with the client.

meaning: To be more advanced or innovative than others.
example_1: Their company is ahead of the curve in AI development.
example_2: She’s ahead of the curve in marketing trends.

meaning: To take a risk or support something uncertain.
example_1: She went out on a limb to defend her idea.
example_2: He went out on a limb by investing early.

meaning: To make a good impression by acting positively and confidently.
example_1: She put her best foot forward during the interview.
example_2: He always puts his best foot forward at meetings.

meaning: To cause a noticeable impact or attract attention, often by challenging norms.
example_1: Her bold ideas made waves in the industry.
example_2: He made waves with his controversial speech.
quiz_options: To attract attention or cause disruption

meaning: To aim for something very ambitious or difficult to achieve.
example_1: She’s always encouraged her students to reach for the stars.
example_2: He reached for the stars and built a successful company.

idiom: give someone the benefit of the doubt
meaning: To choose to believe someone, even if you're not sure they’re telling the truth.
example_1: I’ll give him the benefit of the doubt — maybe he really forgot.
example_2: She gave her colleague the benefit of the doubt after the mistake.

idiom: bite the hand that feeds you
meaning: To harm or act against someone who helps or supports you.
example_1: He bit the hand that fed him by criticizing his mentor.
example_2: Don’t bite the hand that feeds you — be grateful.
quiz_options: To harm someone who helps you

meaning: To support and protect someone, especially in difficult situations.
example_1: Don’t worry — I’ve got your back.
example_2: She always has her team’s back during tough times.

meaning: To betray someone or sacrifice them for personal gain.
example_1: He threw his colleague under the bus to save his own job.
example_2: She felt thrown under the bus during the meeting.
quiz_options: To betray someone for personal gain

meaning: To be completely different from each other.
example_1: My brother and I are like chalk and cheese.
example_2: Their personalities are like chalk and cheese — it’s surprising they’re friends.

meaning: To avoid becoming too close or emotionally involved with someone.
example_1: He keeps most people at arm’s length.
example_2: She kept her ex at arm’s length after the breakup.

meaning: To deliberately ignore something wrong or inappropriate.
example_1: The manager turned a blind eye to the late arrivals.
example_2: She turned a blind eye to the cheating in class.

meaning: To be liked or approved by someone, especially a person in authority.
example_1: She’s in the boss’s good books after finishing the project early.
example_2: He’s trying to get back in her good books after the argument.

idiom: walk a mile in someone’s shoes
meaning: To understand someone’s experience by imagining yourself in their situation.
example_1: Try walking a mile in her shoes before judging her.
example_2: He learned empathy by walking a mile in his father’s shoes.

meaning: In a place that is not well known or frequently visited.
example_1: We found a quiet beach off the beaten track.
example_2: She prefers destinations that are off the beaten track.
quiz_options: In a remote or less-visited place

meaning: To feel a strong desire to travel or move around.
example_1: After a few months at home, I started to have itchy feet.
example_2: She’s always had itchy feet — never stays in one place for long.

meaning: To be at a point where a major decision must be made.
example_1: He’s at a crossroads in his career.
example_2: After graduation, she found herself at a crossroads.

idiom: throw your hat in the ring
meaning: To announce your intention to compete or participate.
example_1: She threw her hat in the ring for the leadership role.
example_2: He finally threw his hat in the ring and applied for the job.
quiz_options: To join a competition or challenge

meaning: To travel frequently and not stay in one place for long.
example_1: He’s been living out of a suitcase since the tour began.
example_2: She lived out of a suitcase for months while working abroad.
